course_name: Cellular biology and biochemistry for engineers
comments: ["I took Cellular biology for engineers, the lectures were interesting (hey I know how DNA replication works and why cancer happens!) and perfectly accessible (I didn't like biology nor chemistry at school and remembered approx nothing). The only assessment is the exam, but after doing the exercises it is not hard (not super easy and not super forgiving tho, I ended up with a 5).\n*sourced from the web", 'The course is a good intro to learning the basics and is interesting. You learn stuff to talk about at parties. However, the exam is close to the exercises but more advanced. Take them seriously. The exam is okayish, but the grading is quit harsh.', 'The course is interesting and useful if you want a minor in the field of life sciences. The first few lectures are a bit less interesting. The course is mainly about genomics and genetics. The biochemistry part is very short (one lecture) and the course does not cover parts like the components of a cell. The main topics are DNA, replication of DNA, transcription and translation, genetics (Mendel and Morgan) and UPGMA (an phylogenetic algorithm).', 'I would not recommend it unless it is mandatory ………….']
tips: ['Go to the lectures and do the exercises. Pay attention to the statics stuff.', 'It is not necessary to go to class, but I recommend it, because the professor repeats multiple times the information needed for the exam. The most useful lecture is the one in week 14, where the professor solves all the exercises of the exam of the previous year.', 'Learn to do the exercises of the exam (always the same) and out as much theory as possible in the cheat sheet']

comments: ['You will learn new things but usually with not a lot of depth except one or two subjects. The slides are not enough at all to understand the subject. Just coming to class is enough to understand everything']
tips: ['Exams questions are almost always the exact sames, the teacher will usually use the last few classes to go over them. You can use internet and your computer during the exam.']

course_name: Cell and developmental biology for engineers
comments: ["The professors try to make the course as interesting as possible, so the exercise sessions are very varied -- field trip, microscope labs, guest lectures, computer simulations. These make the course very interesting. The professors explain okay-well, but overall it's a very interesting course.", "Two professors give lectures. They always try to make it interactive and to learn the names of everyone which feels nice ! The topics require a good understanding of basic molecular biology but try to build engineering intuition on what is learnt and touch topics that we don't really see in other courses. Some exercices sessions are made peculiar formats (eg guest lectures, interactive/computational simulations, field excursion, microscopy,...) and are really appreciable. However these exercices do not exactly ressemble the exercices on the exam so this can be confusing.", 'My favourite course at EPFL. The content is very interesting, the professors explain well and are extremely nice, both excellent teachers. I definitely recommend it!']
tips: ["And there are two continuous controls, because you don't need to learn everything at once. The first part of the course (embryology) is harder.", "The exam is open book (electronic devices authorized if offline). Knowing where to find the information is more important that knowing it by heart. The professors like to insist on the reflexion. Each professor writes a part of the exam on their own topic. Oats' parts are usually easier than Gönczy's.", "The first part is harder than the second, and don't underestimate the exam just because it is open book. The questions require a lot of thinking and a really good global comprehension of the material."]

comments: ['It is an interesting course that is rather easy on the theoretical side if you have done Biomicroscopy I and Image Processing I. comments: ["The course is well presented and it's obvious the profs are making a lot of efforts. Presentation varies from one prof to another. The third part of the course does not seem to have a strong connection with the first two.', 'The quality of the lecture depends a lot on the teacher. comments: ['Very interesting course, with a lot of real life examples (thanks covid for once). comments: ["The subjects studied are very interesting, and the professors are very good too. However, the previous statement is highly dependent on which papers you are assigned. I would highly recommend you take this class in MA3 and not MA1. Having previous knowledge in neuroscience and literature review is almost mandatory if you don't want to spend 20h per week on this class.", 'The professor recently changed to Pr La Manno which made it the first time it was given by him the year i took it and changed the topic to *developmental* neurology and not neurology in general. I think this made the course a little harder because people usually either had knowledge on embryology or on neurology but not really both so personal research during the semester to understand the papers were inevitable, which added to the workload. But it was still very interesting in my opinion, and the professor still gave papers recommendations for those basis that you may not have. Appart from that, this course does not have much content on itself since it is based on paper review and journal clubs literally only given by the students. Except maybe for the first 2-3 weeks where the professor gave a wide presentation on the subject (not really understandable in my opinion) and then a mock journal club with TAs to give us a hint of what was expected, all the work was to do at home to read and analyse the papers which took forever in my opinion. This may slightly change in the next years because we really complained about that but I think the professor aims in having a "demanding" course and thus in putting very higher expectations that necessary for a 4 credits course. He was not even present in most of the journal clubs, but the TA was really nice and gave us good feedback whenever needed.']
tips: ["Good luck lol. No seriously, there's no advice. What is asked of you is to understand the paper and talk about it. You will spend a LOT of time on it because you can't read and understand a paper, as well as write a presentation in 4h (unless you are very good at it). My advice on taking it in MA3 stands. It really helps already knowing about the subjects of the paper beforehand.", "For the journal clubs, the TA said they expected us to spend ~6h a week to read and analyse the papers but honestly we all spend minimum 10h on them to do so. The subjects were also so specific that you always had to do additional research to understand most of it well enough to then only be able to criticise and analyse the paper. The last four weeks are dedicated to group projects (so no journal clubs) which was very different but was kinda fun. Just also took forever :,). We had to re-do a computational data analysis from a given paper and a methodology retrieval from another one. The data analysis took definitely more time and effort. Problem was each group had a different paper so you could not really discuss and compare. And the professor and TA could just give us broad advice of what to do for the analysis since they hadn't done it themselves and were expecting us to have our own ideas or whatever. The methodology retrieval was okay and quite easy to do actually. That said, in the end they gave really good grades because they knew they were going hard on us so it's quite easy have a good grade (>5), and the subject is really interesting but just be prepared to spend lots of time and energy on this, and mostly on your own, even if the TA's very available for questions and directions."]

comments: ['I took it in Fall 2019, have to say that Prof. De Michele is really good and clear. Is a deep systems course, so the solutions have to be really precise. You work on understanding how to design chips given the logic gates they will have and all the optimization steps. The practical lab is rather simple, but also helpful as it is a hands-on approach.', 'I took the course in the 2024 spring semester and it is now called Embedded Systems Design. The course is challenging if you are new to hardware design. Learned a lot from the practical assignments.', "This course is now being taught by Mr. Kluter, who already has some reputation in the CS department. To sum up: he often does not show up to the lectures, he lacks communication skills (for ex. some of the lab requirements were not stated at all; still got penalized for missing them in the hand-in..) and his grading is inexact at best and harsh at worst. This course reflected all of these flaws. This is a 100% project based course, not only in the sense that the projects are the only thing affecting your grade, but also that the lecture material is almost completely useless. Even though we now use Verilog instead of VHDL, the aged nature of the tools used is still painfully apparent, slowing you down considerably. The final project (50% of the grade) was also wayyy too ambitious for a 6-credit course, especially with barely any additional guidance, even when taking the prof's own proposed baseline project. What doesn't help is the harsh grading: we had components which perfectly mimicked the reference implementation, and still ended up with barely half the points, most of the time. I know this is the first year Mr. Kluter teaches this course, and I hope he will address a lot of these issues because the content is very interesting, even if the course does not make good use of it."]
tips: ['Despite the homeworks are individual, nothing impedes you to discuss the problem with your peers, or even do them together. All discrete mathematics background and logic gates is very welcome.', 'I found that test benching is usually always the quickest way to debug the hardware', "Make sure to get a firm grasp on HDL languages like Verilog / VHDL; even though they look and seem to behave like normal programming languages, on silicon this changes dramatically with undefined behavior, catching you off guard most of the time. Prepare to spend significant time on debugging, testbenches are the fastest way to do so. Use EPFL's VDI for building: DO NOT try to install the tools on your own machine, your hair will fall out"]

comments: ['A very good course if you want to deep into the state of the art of NLP and Deep learning. From classical NLP to modern techniques, such as ChatGPT, PaLM techniques.', "Was the first time the course took place, but I liked the topic and some important NLP concept apeared. However we didn't look at the material in a rigerous way, we just applied the algorithms without looking at the math.", 'Not in depth at all, but good overview of current NLP trends and techniques. Given that most tech companies are trying to integrate their own chatbots in everything they can, this is a good course to have a project to showcase and answer interview questions. If you want something more technical / scientific, take another course.', "don't take this class unless you really want/need to learn about nlp. Workload is high for no reason, schedule has an assigment deadline and an assignment release during spring break. You can't even drop this class after the second week. It's a shame because otherwise the content is good.", 'I would only recommend this course if you are comfortable with Python and willing to invest a lot of time into the assignments and project. The lectures are interesting, but you learn the most from the actual assignments. You get 8 credits for this course, so a heavy workload should be expected, especially since there is no exam. However, it sometimes still feels like excessive work. You will likely need to spend some money on Google Colab, as model training can take a long time (especially for the project), but probably not more than $30-50 in total. The lecturer and staff are very good. The TAs respond quickly and answer questions in the discussion forum better than in most other classes.', '- This course was a roller coaster of emotions. Basically, a very modern course about the most up-to-date well defined NLP contents. It is extremely interesting because of that but the amount of work is enormous and not worth 8 ECTs - The course was given by prof. Antoine. He explains incredibly well and he’s extremely fluent in English, so there will be no communication issues. The classes are recorded and of very high quality. However, despite only mentioning the ML theoretical course as a background, they seem to assume you have some background knowledge in model frameworks, such as TensorFlow. Then, some of the most theoretical parts of the course only touch the surface and are briefly explained, which further makes it seem like they expected us to know such things (such as LSTMs) in a very detailed way, given what was later asked in the assignments. - There were three assignments (40%) and a project (60%) - The first assignment was EXTREMELY difficult and lengthy, while only being worth 10%. Me and many people pondered dropping the course. There were also many unclear things and, although there were TAs answering very fast on Ed, answers to the unclear things got scattered around and it was very hard to be aware of every single detail that was missing. There were other problems, such qs not having enough compute to do everything required. Many complains were made and prof. Antoine responded and, although it fixed some organizational issues, like allowing for more TAs to answer questions, the part of “it’s too much work” basically got responded with “it will get better”. - Indeed, for Assignment 2, the difficult was drastically reduced but the effort was still there (and didn’t compensate the work for just 10% on assignment 1). - For assignment 3, the difficulty was a bit harder but the duration was a bit reduced and this would be the only assignment I considered fair in terms of work. - For the project, the idea was fantastic: build a chatbot like ChatGPT and we were given a lot of resources to do it, like access to the SCITAD cluster and some reservations where for two weeks the MNLP course would have full access to 80 GPUs. However, sadly, the organization had many problems as well and the work was a lot (e.g. just for the first milestone, we were expected to write an individual paper review, a group report and ask ChatGPT to write two answers for each of 100 questions, and manually rate each answer compared to the other in different aspects, making preference pairs) while some implementation details were never explained nor the purpose of some functions and files - Overall, the organisation of the course had a lot of problems: a lot of things were not clearly explained, at the start there weren’t many TAs to clarify the questions we had been having, etc. at one point there was a post on Ed with >90 likes (~1/3 of the course) of a student complaining about the time and the problems of the first assignment. But, despite the mess, it gradually got better and, of course, given the amount of work required, it was expected that the number of unclear things scaled proportionally. - In any case, despite having criticised the problems a lot, there were a lot of positives and the overall content was very nice, direct, and practical. We were given a lot of resources to learn about and we were given a lot of freedom as well. The assignments were generously graded, I assume because of all the problems. - So, given that, I’d say that, overall, it really depends on your objectives and how free you are during the semester. If you really want to enter the NLP field or learn more about it, this is one of the best courses to do that but it comes at the cost of investing a lot of your time learning extra things and to clarify a lot of unclear goals. I found it very interesting to learn how NLP works and the “behind the scenes” of ChatGPT but it was a very stressful experience at times and I didn’t fully learn stuff because I had many parallel things that didn’t allow me to invest more time. I’d say that all problems would be justified if the course was worth more credits (I’d say 12 ECTs)']
tips: ['Go to the lectures, but more important, do the Homework and the project with time. Cause of the time that you will have to run the models unless you have 4 A100', "Use ChatGPT for the projects and solve it like this 10 times faster. Don't bother about performance of your results.", 'Literally just do the assignments on time, the content is really not hard if you come from EPFL...', 'Go to the lectures and finish assignments asap otherwise you will regret it.', 'The lectures are important in the beginning, but later they are not crucial for the assignments. Start working on the assignments as soon as possible, as they will likely take tens of hours to finish. The same goes for the project. There are also some code exercises; I recommend doing the first 2 or 3, but once the assignments are handed out, focus on them since they are very time-consuming. Assignment 1, even though it only accounts for 10%, is probably the most time-consuming. If you feel you did well on the first assignment, you should do fine on the others. For the project, it is more open-ended, and you have more freedom regarding model size, etc. I would not choose a big model as it will be challenging to train. There is also quite a bit of manual data annotation, which will be tedious. The main tip is to start as early as possible with everything!', 'Just have a high drive to learn NLP, no other time-consuming courses in parallel, and "giving up" thoughts']

The course is sort of messy and the lectures are a bit dispersive, but the professor is very very kind and will respond to any question or observation you might have.
